sentences: Vanessa Lee Carlton (born August 16, 1980) is an American singer-songwriter and pianist.
section: N/A

sentences: Upon completion of her education at the School of American Ballet, Carlton chose to pursue singing instead, performing in New York City bars and clubs while attending college.
section: N/A

sentences: Three months after recording a demo with producer Peter Zizzo, she signed with A&M Records.
section: N/A

sentences: She began recording her album, which was initially unsuccessful until Ron Fair took over.
section: N/A

sentences: Her debut single, "A Thousand Miles," reached the top five on the Billboard Hot 100 in 2002.
section: N/A

sentences: Her debut album, Be Not Nobody, followed and received a platinum certification in the United States.
section: N/A

sentences: Her subsequent albums, Harmonium (2004) and Heroes & Thieves (2007), failed to match the commercial success of the first.
section: N/A

sentences: She produced a fourth album, Rabbits on the Run (2011), independently before seeking a record label to release it.
section: N/A

sentences: Carlton released a holiday EP titled Hear the Bells in November 2012, and released her fifth studio album, Liberman, on October 23, 2015.

== Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: Carlton was born on August 16, 1980, in Milford, Pennsylvania, the first of three children of Edmund "Ed" Carlton, a pilot, and Heidi Lee, a pianist and school music teacher.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: Her two younger siblings are a sister, Gwen, and a brother, Edmund.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: Carlton is Jewish on her mother's side, who is of Russian-Jewish descent.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: Her interest in music began at an early age.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: At the age of two, she visited Disneyland and played "It's a Small World" on the piano when she came home.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: Her mother then began to tutor her.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: She was introduced to classical music from a young age.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: By the age of 9, she had become passionate about ballet.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: In 1994, when Carlton was 14 years old, she enrolled at the School of American Ballet.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: Upon graduation, she put on vocal performances at nightclubs in the community, beginning to feel more comfortable and dynamic on the stage.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===

sentences: She later moved to New York City, attending Columbia University for one year before dropping out.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and youth ===
== Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: 2002–03: Be Not Nobody =
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===
== Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Carlton first met songwriter/producer Peter Zizzo at a singer-songwriter circle.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: A few months later, Zizzo invited Carlton to his studio to record a demo.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Three months after recording the demo, Carlton was signed by Jimmy Iovine to A&M Records and began to record an album, titled Rinse.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: It was never released, but a few tracks were reworked for Be Not Nobody.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: One song, "Carnival," was re-recorded as "Dark Carnival" for the video game SpyHunter 2.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Other tracks included in Rinse are "Interlude" (later known as "A Thousand Miles"), "Rinse," "Ordinary Days" (later known as "Ordinary Day"), "Twilight," "Pretty Baby," "All I Ask," and "Superhero."
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Of these, only the first five are included in her first album, Be Not Nobody.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Other unreleased tracks from her early demo tapes include "Faces," "Meggie Sue," "Little Mary," "Burden," "Wonder," "Devil Dance," and "Last Fall."
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: With her previous unsuccessful recording efforts, Carlton felt there was a lack of direction at her label.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: However, A&M president Ron Fair upon hearing her demo to "A Thousand Miles," began organizing recording sessions for the song, producing and arranging the song himself.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: It became a hit, peaking inside the top five on the Billboard Hot 100 and went on to become the sixth-most-played song of the year, as well as garnering Grammy Award nominations for "Record of the Year," "Song of the Year," and "Best Instrumental Arrangement Accompanying Vocalist(s)."
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Fair would produce the rest of the album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Be Not Nobody was subsequently released in April 2002 and debuted at number five on the Billboard 200 albums chart with 102,000 units sold.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: It went on to sell more than two million copies worldwide.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Two more singles, "Ordinary Day" and "Pretty Baby" were released.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Carlton began touring in support of her debut album, opening for the Goo Goo Dolls and Third Eye Blind, before headlining her own tour at the end of 2002.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: She later toured Europe in 2003.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: Carlton had collaborated with other artists before the release of her second album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===

sentences: She provided the descant vocals for the Counting Crows song "Big Yellow Taxi", played piano for Italian singer Zucchero, along with Haylie Ecker on violin for the song "Indaco Dagli Occhi Del Cielo," and provided backing vocals for "Moving On" by Kimya Dawson for her album Hidden Vagenda.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–03: Be Not Nobody ===
== Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: 2004–05: Harmonium ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: Carlton's second album, Harmonium was released in November 2004.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: Harmonium debuted at number 33 on the Billboard 200 and descended quickly after, selling fewer than 150,000 copies as of February 2006, which was considered a disappointment after her successful debut.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: It was produced by Stephan Jenkins from rock band Third Eye Blind, and included darker themes than those on her debut album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: Carlton and Jenkins met and began a relationship in mid-2002, when she and Third Eye Blind, of which Jenkins is lead singer, were on tour together.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: After seeing Carlton perform live, Jenkins entered her dressing room and expressed interest in producing her music, and according to Carlton they "decided very quickly, that we had the same vision for the album".
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: Carlton credited Jenkins with helping her to withstand and protect herself from pressures the record label executives, who wanted to influence the recording process, placed on her.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: According to Carlton, her label "wasn't very happy" about the decisions she made during the making of the album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: Carlton stated that the album contained more of her own aesthetic as opposed to Be Not Nobody which was more influenced by Ron Fair.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: A single, "White Houses", released to radio in late August 2004, peaking at number 86 on the Billboard Hot 100.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: MTV censored and later banned the single's music video because of a controversial lyric in the song that refers to sexual intercourse.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: Carlton attributed the censoring of the song to the Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy involving Janet Jackson which had occurred earlier that year.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: To support the album, Carlton embarked on a North American concert tour, which began on October 21, and concluded on November 21; her opening act was Low Millions.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: A second tour, with Cary Brothers and Ari Hest as supporting acts, ran from March 9 to April 30.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: Carlton left A&M Records in mid-2005 as she felt that her nonconformist attitude would have created problems for her at the label in the future.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: A&M Records had sent Carlton into the recording studio because they wanted to re-release Harmonium, whereas Carlton felt the album should be promoted as it was.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: During her studio time, in which she wrote songs with Linda Perry and The Matrix, she had what she called a "revelation" about leaving the label to find another record deal once promotion for Harmonium had ended.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

sentences: In the same period she collaborated with the Italian singer Zucchero Fornaciari featuring his song Indaco Dagli Occhi Del Cielo (cover of the well known Everybody's Got to Learn Sometime), together with the violinist Haylie Ecker, in the album Zu & Co.
section: == Life and career == | === 2004–05: Harmonium ===

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: As a teenager, Vanessa Carlton suffered from depression and developed anorexia after completing high school.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: She sought therapy, managed her depression with medication, and overcame her eating disorder before her first single debuted.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On June 19, 2010, Carlton came out as bisexual while headlining Nashville Pride.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: She stated to the attending audience, "I've never said this before, but I am a proud bisexual woman.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: "On October 9, 2013, at a live performance in Bay Shore, New York, Carlton announced that she was expecting her first child with her fiancé John McCauley (of the band Deer Tick).
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In November, she announced she had experienced an ectopic pregnancy, in which she later suffered a ruptured tube and internal bleeding.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: After surgery, her entire right fallopian tube was removed.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On December 27, 2013, Carlton and McCauley married in a ceremony officiated by Stevie Nicks.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On June 26, 2014, Carlton announced via Facebook that the release of Liberman would be delayed until the summer of 2015 because she was expecting another child with McCauley.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On January 13, 2015, Carlton gave birth to her first child, a daughter named Sidney.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Charity work ==
section: == Charity work ==

sentences: In 2005, Carlton completed the New York City Marathon and donated the pledge money she collected to Musicians on Call, a nonprofit organization that brings live and recorded music to patients' bedsides.
